articles.author: MARK SHERMAN
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — The Supreme Court on Thursday unanimously preserved access to a medication that was used in nearly two-thirds of all abortions in the U.S.
articles.title: Unanimous Supreme Court preserves access to widely used abortion medication

articles.author: MARK SHERMAN
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — The Supreme Court on Thursday unanimously ruled against a man who wants to trademark the suggestive phrase “Trump too small.”
articles.title: Supreme Court rules California man can't trademark 'Trump too small'

articles.author: LISA MASCARO
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — Donald Trump made a triumphant return Thursday to Capitol Hill, whipping up House and Senate Republicans in his first meetings since the Jan.6, 2021 attacks, embraced by GOP lawmakers who find themselves newly energized by his bid to retake the White House.
articles.title: Trump returns to Capitol Hill and whips up Republican lawmakers, a first meeting since Jan. 6 attack

articles.description: MOSCOW (AP) — U.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich, who has been jailed for over a year in Russia on espionage charges, will stand trial in the Ural Mountains city of Yekaterinburg, where he was detained, authorities said Thursday.
articles.title: US reporter Evan Gershkovich, jailed in Russia on espionage charges, to stand trial, officials say

articles.author: NICOLE WINFIELD, PAOLO SANTALUCIA and COLLEEN LONG
articles.description: BORGO EGNAZIA, Italy (AP) — A Group of Seven summit opened Thursday with agreement reached on a U.S. proposal to back a $50 billion loan to Ukraine using frozen Russian assets as collateral, giving Kyiv a strong show of support even as Europe's political chessboard shifts to the right.
articles.title: G7 summit opens with deal to use Russian assets for Ukraine as EU's traditional powers recalibrate

articles.author: JACQUES BILLEAUD
articles.description: PHOENIX (AP) — Phoenix police violate people’s rights, discriminate against Black, Hispanic and Native American people when enforcing the law and use excessive force, including unjustified deadly force, the U.S.
articles.title: Phoenix police have pattern of violating civil rights and using excessive force, Justice Dept. says

articles.author: FREIDA FRISARO, TERRY SPENCER and DANIEL KOZIN
articles.description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) — A tropical disturbance that brought a rare flash flood emergency to much of southern Florida delayed flights at two of the state's largest airports and left vehicles waterlogged and stalled in some of the region's lowest lying streets.
articles.title: Stalled cars in flooded streets leave South Florida looking like a scene from a zombie movie

articles.author: GENE JOHNSON
articles.description: SEATTLE (AP) — The United States granted the Makah Indian Tribe in Washington state a long-sought waiver Thursday that helps clear the way for its first sanctioned whale hunts since 1999.The Makah, a tribe of 1,500 people on the northwestern tip of the Olympic Peninsula, is the only Native American tribe with a treaty that specifically mentions a right to hunt whales.
articles.title: Washington state's Makah tribe clears major hurdle toward resuming traditional whale hunts

articles.author: TOM KRISHER
articles.description: DETROIT (AP) — Tesla shareholders are charting the future of the electric vehicle company Thursday as they wrap up voting whether or not to restore CEO Elon Musk's massive pay package that was thrown out by a Delaware judge.
articles.title: Shareholders are charting Tesla's future as voting on CEO Elon Musk's pay package comes to a head

articles.author: ROB MAADDI
articles.description: The Atlanta Falcons were stripped of a fifth-round pick in next year's draft on Thursday for violating the NFL’s anti-tampering rules prior to signing quarterback Kirk Cousins, wide receiver Darnell Mooney and tight end Charlie Woerner in free agency in March.
articles.title: Atlanta Falcons forfeit fifth-round pick, fined for tampering with Kirk Cousins
